sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Candida endophthalmitis: alternative therapy, 200 mg IV on day 1, followed by 100 mg IV once daily for at least 4 to 6 weeks
  • Candidemia: 200 mg IV on day 1, then 100 mg IV once daily; continue for at least 14 days after the last positive culture
  • Candidiasis, Cardiovascular system infection: 200 mg IV on day 1, followed by 100 to 200 mg IV once daily
  • Candidiasis, Osteoarticular infection: alternative therapy, 200 mg IV on day 1, then 100 mg IV once daily for at least 2 weeks, followed by fluconazole therapy
  • Candidiasis of the esophagus: 100 mg IV on day 1, then 50 mg IV every day for a minimum of 14 days and for at least 7 days following resolution of symptoms (manufacturer dosing)
  • Candidiasis of the esophagus: (alternative therapy) 200 mg IV on day 1, followed by 100 mg IV daily for 14 to 21 days (guideline dosing)
  • Candidiasis of the esophagus - HIV infection: 100 mg IV on day 1, then 50 mg IV once daily for a minimum of 14 days and for at least 7 days following resolution of symptoms (manufacturer dosing) OR for a total duration of 14 to 21 days (guideline dosing)
  • Disseminated candidiasis, chronic: alternative therapy, 200 mg IV on day 1, then 100 mg IV once daily for 1 to 2 weeks, followed by oral fluconazole therapy when clinically stable
  • Disseminated candidiasis, Intra-abdominal and peritonitis: 200 mg IV on day 1, then 100 mg IV once daily; continue for at least 14 days after the last positive culture
  • Empirical antifungal therapy, Suspected candidiasis in non-neutropenic patients: primary therapy, 200 mg IV on day 1, followed by 100 mg IV once daily until cultures and/or serodiagnostic tests are negative
  • HIV infection - Oropharyngeal candidiasis: (fluconazole-refractory) 100 mg IV on day 1, then 50 mg IV daily
  • Oropharyngeal candidiasis: (alternative therapy) 200 mg IV on day 1, followed by 100 mg IV once daily

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• safety and efficacy in pediatric patients 16 years of age and younger have not been established
  • Candidemia: greater than 16 years old, 200 mg IV on day 1, then 100 mg IV once daily; continue for at least 14 days after the last positive culture
  • Candidiasis of the esophagus: greater than 16 years old, 100 mg IV on day 1, then 50 mg IV once daily for a minimum of 14 days and for at least 7 days following resolution of symptoms (manufacturer dosing)
  • Candidiasis of the esophagus - HIV infection: greater than 16 years old, 100 mg IV on day 1, then 50 mg IV once daily for a minimum of 14 days and for at least 7 days following resolution of symptoms (manufacturer dosing)
  • Disseminated candidiasis, Intra-abdominal and peritonitis: greater than 16 years old, 200 mg IV on day 1, then 100 mg IV once daily; continue for at least 14 days after the last positive culture

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• hepatic: no dosage adjustment necessary
  • renal: no dosage adjustment necessary
  • geriatric: no dosage adjustment necessary

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Candidemia
  • Candidiasis of the esophagus
  • Candidiasis of the esophagus - HIV infection
  • Disseminated candidiasis, Intra-abdominal and peritonitis
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Candida endophthalmitis
  • Candidiasis, Cardiovascular system infection
  • Candidiasis, Osteoarticular infection
  • Disseminated candidiasis, chronic
  • Empirical antifungal therapy, Suspected candidiasis in non-neutropenic patients
  • HIV infection - Oropharyngeal candidiasis
  • Oropharyngeal candidiasis

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: hypersensitivity to anidulafungin, any component of the product, or other echinocandins

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• anaphylactic reactions, including shock, have been reported; discontinue use
  • infusion-related reactions, including rash, urticaria, flushing, pruritus, bronchospasm, dyspnea, and hypotension, have been reported; to reduce occurrence, do not exceed an infusion rate of 1.1 mg/min
  • hepatitis, hepatic failure, and significant hepatic dysfunction have been reported; monitoring recommended
  • report suspected adverse reactions to the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• WHO: Compatible with breastfeeding. Monitor infant for side effects.
  • Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Endocrine metabolic:Hypokalemia (3.1%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea (3.1%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Deep venous thrombosis (0.8%)
  • Hepatic:Abnormal liver function, Hepatic necrosis (less than 2%)
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis, Hypersensitivity reaction
  • Neurologic:Seizure (less than 2%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Anidulafungin inhibits the synthesis of beta (1,3)-D-glucan, an essential component of the cell wall of filamentous fungi.

1.title: Distribution
1.mono:
• Protein binding: greater than 99%
  • Vd: healthy subjects, 30 to 50 L
  • Vd: immunocompromised pediatric patients, 0.434 L/kg to 0.537 L/kg
  • Vd: infants, 0.9 L/kg
  • Vd: neonates, 1.7 L/kg

2.title: Metabolism
2.mono:
• Hepatic: none observed (not a substrate, inducer, or inhibitor of CYP450)
  • Undergoes slow chemical degradation at physiologic temperature and pH to a ring-opened peptide (inactive)

3.title: Excretion
3.mono:
• Fecal: healthy adults, 30%.
  • Renal: healthy adults, less than 1%
  • Dialyzable: no (hemodialysis)
  • Total body clearance: patients with fungal infection, 1 L/hr
  • Total body clearance: children, 0.0159 L/kg/hr to 0.0175 L/kg/hr
  • Total body clearance: infants, 0.015 L/kg/hr
  • Total body clearance: neonates, 0.02 L/kg/hr

4.title: Elimination Half Life
4.mono:
• Patients with fungal infections: 26.5 hours
  • Pediatric patients: 19.9 to 23.1 hours

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • reconstitute with Sterile Water for Injection only; reconstituted drug should be further diluted with D5W or NS only
  • total infusion volumes for administration: 50 mg dose=65 mL (15 mL of drug and 50 mL of solution); 100 mg dose=130 mL (30 mL of drug and 100 mL of solution); 200 mg dose=260 mL (60 mL of drug and 200 mL of solution)
  • the diluted solution in the infusion bag may be stored at room temperature up to 25 degrees C (77 degrees F) for up to 48 hours or frozen for at least 72 hours prior to administration
  • rate of infusion should not exceed 1.1 mg/min (1.4 mL/min or 84 mL/hr when reconstituted and diluted as instructed)

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• culture and susceptibility tests during treatment, if appropriate
  • signs and symptoms of Candida fungal infection; improvement is indicative of efficacy
  • signs and symptoms of worsening hepatic function in patients who develop abnormal liver function tests during therapy

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This drug may cause nausea, diarrhea, vomiting, pyrexia, insomnia, headache, or dyspepsia.
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of new or worsening hepatic dysfunction.
  • Tell patient to report signs/symptoms of anaphylactic or hypersensitivity reactions (eg, anaphylactic shock, rash, urticaria, flushing, pruritus, bronchospasm, dyspnea, or hypotension).
  • Instruct female patients of childbearing potential to notify their physician if they become or plan to become pregnant while receiving treatment.
  • Instruct female patients to notify their healthcare provider if they are breastfeeding or intend to breastfeed during therapy.
